comments.commentBody:
I guess you Don't Mess Around With Tim! The tricky clues were Bad Bad, Leroy Brown. I will unhat myself to Mr. Croce and the ten things that caused my brain to rethink thinking.
@Martin...'is tat en island?' made me laugh like I was eight and heard it for the first time. I read they were making an animated film about Ajax, called Troy Story II coming out in 3D. Actually, I think the Troy Store Acts and Eder Foots Scam down triplets are as good as yesterday's Magic Word diagonal. Great debut and almost thirty minutes of fun for me.
Great debut, Tim.  Congratulations!  My favorite clues:  18, 37, 58 across; 9 down.
How obscure is Ema Savahl? Obscure enough to never have been mentioned in the New York Times, per the ProQuest newspaper database.

OBAMA EATS ENDANGERED BELUGA STURGEON WITH PUTIN

Quote:
Russian agencies, quoting the government's press service, said Putin treated Obama to black caviar with sour cream, smoked beluga with pancakes and tea made in the traditional Russian samovar, a big coal-fired kettle.

http://www.reuters.com...

http://www.reuters.com...

WIKIPEDIA:
IUCN classifies the beluga as Endangered. It is a protected species listed in appendix III of the Bern Convention and its trade is restricted under CITES appendix II. The Mediterranean population is strongly protected under appendix II of the Bern Convention, prohibiting any intentional killing of these fish.

The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has banned imports of Beluga Caviar and other beluga products from the Caspian Sea since October 6, 2005.

as someone who ran the kitchen of a struggling restaurant for several years, i can relate with the restaurant's actions...to a point.

it's absolutely fair to charge a cakeage fee, but since they all shared one slice of cake, shouldn't they have simply been charged for one restaurant dessert and not four? and come on, for $25 they should have gotten a ceramic plate to eat on.

I got this 7 Layer Bars recipe from a friend:

1 package graham cracker crumbs mixed with a stick of butter
Press flat into a jelly roll pan.
Sprinkle on:
1+ cup of chocolate chips
1+ cup of butterscotch chips
2 cups of coconut flakes
1+ cup of chopped walnuts
2 cans of sweetened condensed milk

Bake until brown and gooey in a 350 degree oven.
Wait until they are cool! Cut into squares.

(Omit the nuts if you must, but then they will be 6 layer bars!)
Jamie
Bring on the apron! Let's show them that our kids should have food from a kitchen not from a factory!

just to clarify, this was supposed to be a taste testing of one forkful for the two people who had not been at the shoot and then they would wrap it to take it home. if you look at the photo you will see along side the bill the two pieces of cake that were not eaten except for two bites.

woody asked for ONE plate and 2 forks. and we had every intention of buying dessert. woody is from minnesota and has never had a problem with this. he agreed to allow me to come clean that it was not i who asked for the plate and 2 forks. nancy suggested i tell them "who i am" and i said no. then it occurred to me that if i gave the card to the pastry chef she would be my ally and understand as we pastry chefs are very supportive of each other but unfortunately she wasn't there.

I've never actually seen or experienced the hard shake, but I understand it is supposed to flavor the drink differently.  I don't know if I could afford the price tag, but I'll try to pick up the book.
This is ridiculous.  A forkage fee?  Really...the dishwashing expenses for those forks must have cost so much.

This is rich! You try to show your friends that you're hot doodie in the "food community" but you get shut down HARD by some minimum wage waiter. Your ego is too big to just suck it up, so you stiff the waiter (who is just doing his job).

The part I love most is that you're so utterly pompus that you can't help but damage your reputation by whining to the world about how badly you've been treated. All over a stupid piece of cake.

I am indulging in schadenfreude!

You bake treats for a living. Get over it.

Sorry, but I think Rose is in the wrong here. Let me present the restaurant's side here: The whole point of corkage (and yes, cakeage) fees are to make up for lost revenue -- desserts not ordered from the menu, the cutlery and plates provided, and the extra time the table is occupied when it could be turned over to another paying customer. Corkage and cakeage are also meant to allow patrons to bring in something *special* that isn't available from the restaurant: some special vintage wine, a decorated birthday cake, etc. NOT some leftover cake in a takeaway box. Also, it's common practice to inform the restaurant while making the reservation that you would like to bring in something, partly to make sure that both sides are clear on what's going on, fees involved, and the server is properly informed.

Restaurants aren't charitable operations. They exist to make a profit! Clearly, the server could've handled the situation in a better way, but I don't see why people are so outraged.

Julia's Love Child
http://juliaslovechild.tumblr.com

Bookseller

She didn't use their facilities for nothing, she bought lunch. Then when she pulled out a pastry, the reason for the lunch was so that she could try this pastry with her friends, they charged her $25 after "reporting" her to the chef. There was a time when restaurants were expected to offer hospitality, not a bad attitude. But that was before Gen X of course.

When a restaurant is deliberately rude to me, as the Breslin was to Ms. Beranbaum, I do two things. First, I stiff the waiter, who should expect this since he is deliberately being rude to me so I won't come back, and second, I don't go back. Third, and even better, is telling people what jerks they are at that restaurant so others won't go either.
First proposing to ban salt and now this, what's the deal with politicians' assault on real food in New York?
Ha ha, dude standing in front of Bols Blue Curaco and wants $675 to learm from him.  Cue laugh track!!!
It's pretty simple. If the waiter had ditched the attitude (in other words ... been a good waiter) and had explained the forkage fee up front, there wouldn't have been any issue.

The curious thing about Ray Sokolov's refusal of the new assignment is that he did once write a very fine column about the ethnology of food for Natural History magazine. Hard to swallow the explanation of his departure.

Solved it all, except had to Google RHETT Akins and "The Vengeance of SHE."  I hadn't heard of either one.  I learned that a MARES NEST is a hoax and that EULER introduced the e symbol for natural logs (whatever they are).  Schwalm-EDER was new to me as well.  Isn't the opposite of very "Not at all," rather than ATAD?  A challenging puzzle.  I enjoyed it.

Hey, Tim - I'll be in Torrington on April 8th to see David Sedaris at the Warner.  Meet me there!  You can bring the Advil I now feel that you owe me, and I'll bring a TUPAC to wash it down with.  I was feeling rather confident, having breezed through every puzzle this week...  Here's how bad it was: I was born 10 miles from Fenway Park, but spent a good part of Grey's Anatomy trying to figure out what Redskins fans wear on their feet!

Berenbaum was totally in the wrong here. If she's in the food industry one would think she would be aware of restaurant etiquette, and know that it is somewhat rude to bring her own food. Some restaurants do allow patrons to serve their own cakes and desserts for special occasions but that involves calling ahead and clearing it first. Seems as though Ms. Berenbaum is so full of herself that she thought the restaurant would bend the rules for her.

As for the "rudeness" of the waiter, I wonder on that, as well. No server in his right mind is going to accept food from strangers, and it seems as though that offended Ms. Berenbaum more than anything else. What else did he say, that it was a restaurant? Well, wasn't it? Not to mention that the server likely HAD to report the situation. The managers probably thought that charging for the forks was less disruptive than ejecting the party. Something tells me the Breslin isn't going to lament the fact that Ms. Berenbaum won't be back, and I can't blame them.

(and no I don't work for them, but I've worked in customer service and have had one too many clients like this...customers who suddenly decide I'm "rude" because I'm trying to do my job and enforce house rules. It's not being rude; it's called doing one's job)

Oh-oh. I'm feeling good!

Twenty minutes in and things looked bleak; I had big areas of open space. But - nibble, nibble - and a word or two would fall into place. For instance, I was trying to do (R)ED S(WOOSH) or something - I never expected it would be my local ball team that was being referred to.

Many of the clues took time to finally fall into the proper cadence. Lots of fun.

-- jpgaskell

Tired, brain-dead, and slow tonight. Thought I was doing well when I quickly filled in 15A and 16A (see below), but those erroneous entries quickly hosed up my NW and NE. Got a toehold with PESO crossing EGYPT, and working around and up, Anne E.-style. My favorite was when 42A was the improbable but correct ____SX____.

Beautiful Entries: stacked 9s in the NE and SW, bien sur, plus SCAREDY CAT, TAKES X-RAYS, ALPHABET SOUP, RED SOX NATION, ICE SCRAPER, SERAPES, GLITCH

Clever Clues: "Their points are made bluntly," "Slow to mix, say," "Attachment used with care?" "Metropolitan hangover?" "Chain link?" "Rum, to some," "It takes folks in," "Wedding ring?"

Misdirection: thinking literal not figurative for "Eat up," player not party item for "One suspended," arena (or O-RENA) not player for "Magic center, once," food not drink for "Fried"

Errors: LORNA for DOONE, NEVA RIVER for URAL RIVER, COLA for NEHI, PEARL for ALDER [!!], ATRA for TRAC

Wikipedia Worthy: Leonhard EULER, TUPAC Shakur, Schwalm-EDER, JOE PALOOKA, SETH Meyers (not Mike Myers!), TROY, RHETT Akins (not Chet Atkins!)

Crosswordese: DR. T (13/14), the crossword puzzle's favorite Richard Gere role, not to be confused with MR. T (33), the crossword puzzle's favorite portrayer of Clubber Lang and B.A. Baracas

Gripes: e is not the symbol for natural logs, it's the base of the natural logarithm
The parking rules on Sixth Street correspond to the business of the Federal building and the Civic Center. In that sense, one may ask, who or what is it that is out of sync?
Cry union babies cry. you only have yourself to blame. Should get rid of them all and start over.
Geese guys, not everyone in Berkeley conforms to a stereotype.  There are plenty of normal people who live there for a variety of reasons.  Easy transportation, good weather, etc.
